div.p: Experiment title: Investigations of phase transitions on Eu compounds by nuclear resonance scattering on lslEu applying the crossed polarizer technique

div.head: Report:
div.p: After the first successful nuclear resonance scattering experiment at the 21.5 keV resonance of 151Eu performed by us at the ESRF in October 1995 we report here on nuclear forward scattering (NFS) on Eu compounds undergoing phase transitions. Furtheron we performed the first inelastic nuclear scattering experiment on the isotope 151Eu.

We used a highly monochromatized beam with a bandwidth of ~7meV, the time resolution of the detector system was =1.4ns. The samples were Eu$Sd b and EuS (both polycrystalline) and a single crystal of EuP 0 5 i4, all with natural abundance of 15iEu. EuS which is ferromagnetic below 16.5 K was measured at room temperature (cf. Fig. la) and in a liquid helium cryostat at 4.2 K without magnetic field and in a field of 3.671' applied parallel to the synchrotron beam. The spectra at low temperatures are shown in Fig. lb, c. The fits of these spectra prove that without external field the magnetic moments in the EuS powder are randomly oriented, while with applied field the mag-netization is perfectly aligned along the synchrotron beam. Eu& exhibits two different valence states (Eu2+ and Eu3'), coexisting at low temperatures, leading to a pronounced modulation of the time decay of the nuclear excitation (cf. EuP5014 is of special interest in optics and high pressure studies. Our inelastic nuclear scattering measurement on a single crystal (cf. Fig. 2) is the first experiment of this type at the 151Eu resonance and proves the feasibility of this new technique at 21.54 keV.

The much faster time decay of the nuclear excitation at higher temperatures indicates the presence of fluctuations.
